metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Numbers
JavaScript has only one type of number. Numbers can be written with or without decimals.
content.html: JavaScript has only one type of number. Numbers can be written with or without decimals.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 3.14;    // A number with decimals
let y = 3;       // A number without decimals

content.code:
let x = 3.14;    // A number with decimals
let y = 3;       // A number without decimals

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 3.14;    // A number with decimals
let y = 3;       // A number without decimals

content.code_html:
let x = 3.14;    // A number with decimals
 let y = 3;       // A number without decimals

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 3.14;    // A number with decimals
let y = 3;       // A number without decimals

content.text: Extra large or extra small numbers can be written with scientific (exponent) notation:
content.html: Extra large or extra small numbers can be written with scientific (exponent) notation:

content.code_html:
let x = 123e5;    // 12300000
 let y = 123e-5;   // 0.00123

content.text: JavaScript Numbers are Always 64-bit Floating Point
Unlike many other programming languages, JavaScript does not define different types of numbers, like integers, short, long, floating-point etc.
content.html: Unlike many other programming languages, JavaScript does not define different types of numbers, like integers, short, long, floating-point etc.

content.text: JavaScript numbers are always stored as double precision floating point numbers, following the international IEEE 754 standard. This format stores numbers in 64 bits, where the number (the fraction) is stored in bits 0 to 51, the exponent in bits 52 to 62, and the sign in bit 63:
content.html:
JavaScript numbers are always stored as double precision floating point numbers, following the international IEEE 754 standard.

This format stores numbers in 64 bits, where the number (the fraction) is stored in bits 0 to 51, the exponent in bits 52 to 62, and the sign in bit 63:

content.text: Integer Precision
Integers (numbers without a period or exponent notation) are accurate up to 15 digits.
content.html: Integers (numbers without a period or exponent notation) are accurate up to 15 digits.

content.code_html:
let x = 999999999999999;   // x will be 999999999999999
 let y = 9999999999999999;  // y will be 10000000000000000

content.text: The maximum number of decimals is 17.
content.html: The maximum number of decimals is 17.

content.text: Floating Precision

content.code_html: let x = 0.2 + 0.1;
let x = (0.2 * 10 + 0.1 * 10) / 10;

content.text: Adding Numbers and Strings
WARNING !!
content.html: WARNING !!

content.text: JavaScript uses the + operator for both addition and concatenation.
content.html: JavaScript uses the + operator for both addition and concatenation.

content.text: Numbers are added. Strings are concatenated.
content.html: Numbers are added. Strings are concatenated.

content.text: If you add two numbers, the result will be a number:
content.html: If you add two numbers, the result will be a number:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = 20;
let z = x + y;

content.text: If you add two strings, the result will be a string concatenation:
content.html: If you add two strings, the result will be a string concatenation:

content.code_html:
let x = "10";
let y = "20";
let z = x + y;

content.text: If you add a number and a string, the result will be a string concatenation:
content.html: If you add a number and a string, the result will be a string concatenation:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = "20";
let z = x + y;

content.text: If you add a string and a number, the result will be a string concatenation:
content.html: If you add a string and a number, the result will be a string concatenation:

content.code_html:
let x = "10";
let y = 20;
let z = x + y;

content.text: A common mistake is to expect this result to be 30:
content.html: A common mistake is to expect this result to be 30:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = 20;
let z = "The result is: " + x + y;

content.text: A common mistake is to expect this result to be 102030:
content.html: A common mistake is to expect this result to be 102030:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = 20;
let z = "30";
let result = x + y + z;

content.text: The JavaScript interpreter works from left to right.
content.html: The JavaScript interpreter works from left to right.

content.text: First 10 + 20 is added because x and y are both numbers.
content.html: First 10 + 20 is added because x and y are both numbers.

content.text: Then 30 + "30" is concatenated because z is a string.
content.html: Then 30 + "30" is concatenated because z is a string.

content.text: Numeric Strings
JavaScript strings can have numeric content:
content.html: JavaScript strings can have numeric content:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 100;         // x is a number
let y = "100";       // y is a 
string

content.code:
let x = 100;         // x is a number
let y = "100";       // y is a
string

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 100;         // x is a number
let y = "100";       // y is a 
string

content.code_html:
let x = 100;         // x is a number
let y = "100";       // y is a string

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 100;         // x is a number
let y = "100";       // y is a 
string

content.text: JavaScript will try to convert strings to numbers in all numeric operations:
content.html: JavaScript will try to convert strings to numbers in all numeric operations:

content.text: This will work:
content.html: This will work:

content.code_html:
let x = "100";
let y = "10";
let z = x / y;

content.text: This will also work:
content.html: This will also work:

content.code_html:
let x = "100";
let y = "10";
let z = x * y;

content.text: And this will work:
content.html: And this will work:

content.code_html:
let x = "100";
let y = "10";
let z = x - y;

content.text: But this will not work:
content.html: But this will not work:

content.code_html:
let x = "100";
let y = "10";
let z = x + y;

content.text: In the last example JavaScript uses the + operator to concatenate the strings.
content.html: In the last example JavaScript uses the + operator to concatenate the strings.

content.text: NaN - Not a Number
NaN is a JavaScript reserved word indicating that a number is not a legal number.
content.html: NaN is a JavaScript reserved word indicating that a number is not a legal number.

content.text: Trying to do arithmetic with a non-numeric string will result in NaN (Not a Number):
content.html: Trying to do arithmetic with a non-numeric string will result in NaN (Not a Number):

content.code: let x = 100 / "Apple";
content.code_html: let x = 100 / "Apple";

content.text: However, if the string is numeric, the result will be a number:
content.html: However, if the string is numeric, the result will be a number:

content.code_html: let x = 100 / "10";

content.text: You can use the global JavaScript function isNaN() to find out if a value is a not a number:
content.html: You can use the global JavaScript function isNaN() to find out if a value is a not a number:

content.code: let x = 100 / "Apple";isNaN(x);
content.code_html:
let x = 100 / "Apple";
isNaN(x);

content.text: Watch out for NaN . If you use NaN in a mathematical operation, the result will also be NaN :
content.html: Watch out for NaN. If you use NaN in a mathematical operation, the result will also be NaN:

content.code_html:
let x = NaN;
let y = 5;
let z = x + y;

content.text: Or the result might be a concatenation like NaN5:
content.html: Or the result might be a concatenation like NaN5:

content.code_html:
let x = NaN;
let y = "5";
let z = x + y;

content.text: NaN is a number: typeof NaN returns number :
content.html: NaN is a number: typeof NaN returns number:

content.code: typeof NaN;
content.code_html: typeof NaN;

content.text: Infinity
Infinity (or -Infinity ) is the value JavaScript will return if you calculate a number outside the largest possible number.
content.html: Infinity (or -Infinity) is the value JavaScript will return if you calculate a number outside the largest possible number.

content.code_html:
let myNumber = 2;
// Execute until Infinity
 while (myNumber != Infinity) {
  myNumber = myNumber * myNumber;
}

content.text: Division by 0 (zero) also generates Infinity :
content.html: Division by 0 (zero) also generates Infinity:

content.code:
let x =  2 / 0;
let y = -2 / 0;
content.code_html:
let x =  2 / 0;
let y = -2 / 0;

content.text: Infinity is a number: typeof Infinity returns number .
content.html: Infinity is a number: typeof Infinity returns number.

content.code: typeof Infinity;
content.code_html: typeof Infinity;

content.text: Hexadecimal
JavaScript interprets numeric constants as hexadecimal if they are preceded by 0x.
content.html: JavaScript interprets numeric constants as hexadecimal if they are preceded by 0x.

content.code: let x = 0xFF;
content.code_html: let x = 0xFF;

content.text: Never write a number with a leading zero (like 07). Some JavaScript versions interpret numbers as octal if they are written with a leading zero.
content.html:
Never write a number with a leading zero (like 07).
Some JavaScript versions interpret numbers as octal if they are written with a leading zero.

content.text: By default, JavaScript displays numbers as base 10 decimals.
content.html: By default, JavaScript displays numbers as base 10 decimals.

content.text: But you can use the toString() method to output numbers from base 2 to base 36 .
content.html: But you can use the toString() method to output numbers from base 2 to base 36.

content.text: Hexadecimal is base 16 . Decimal is base 10 . Octal is base 8 . Binary is base 2 .
content.html: Hexadecimal is base 16. Decimal is base 10. Octal is base 8. Binary is base 2.

content.code_html:
let myNumber = 32;
myNumber.toString(32);
myNumber.toString(16);
myNumber.toString(12);
myNumber.toString(10);
myNumber.toString(8);
myNumber.toString(2);

content.text: JavaScript Numbers as Objects
Normally JavaScript numbers are primitive values created from literals:
content.html: Normally JavaScript numbers are primitive values created from literals:

content.code: let x = 123;
content.code_html: let x = 123;

content.text: But numbers can also be defined as objects with the keyword new :
content.html: But numbers can also be defined as objects with the keyword new:

content.code: let y = new Number(123);
content.code_html: let y = new Number(123);

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

content.code:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

content.code_html:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

content.text: Do not create Number objects.
content.html: Do not create Number objects.

content.text: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.
content.html: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.

content.text: Number Objects can produce unexpected results:
content.html: Number Objects can produce unexpected results:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

content.code:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

content.code_html:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

content.code:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

content.code_html:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 500;
let y = new Number(500);

content.text: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y) .
content.html: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

content.code:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

content.code_html:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

content.code:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

content.code_html:
let x = new Number(500);
let y = new Number(500);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

let y = new Number(500);

content.text: Comparing two JavaScript objects always returns false .
content.html: Comparing two JavaScript objects always returns false.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 10; let y = 20; let z = x + y; What will be the result of z ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 10;
let y = 20;
let z = x + y;
What will be the result of z?
